Half-Life: Blue Shift, released by Valve and developed by Gearbox in 2001 is the second to last of the original Half-Life quadrilogy before Half-Life 2.

In this expansion you play as Barney Calhoun, a Black Mesa security guard. Blue Shift takes you through unseen yet similar locations of Black Mesa, and a short trip to Xen. This expansion focuses mainly on fighting the military—a welcome break after fighting tons of aliens in Opposing Force—and escaping the Resonance Cascade all while rescuing scientists along the way. 

Blue Shift is set in the same location and time frame as that of Half-Life except you're on another side of the Black Mesa Research Facility. 

At the start, Barney rides the tram from Area 8 Topside Dormitories on the surface, into the underground sector of Black Mesa. When you arrive at your destination, Area 3 Security Facilities, you find yourself locked out. After some time you are let in and this is where the game truly begins. After entering Area 3 you quickly put on your work uniform and are handed your service weapon. Shortly after this the Resonance Cascade takes place and it all goes to hell.

As Barney you see the disaster from a different perspective. Since you are not at all involved in the disastrous experiment done in the Anomalous Materials sector you see and hear the disaster unfold around you. Barney will slowly but surely gain insight as to what happened through conversation with scientists and by witnessing the military exterminate Black Mesa employees. Upon reaching the climax of Blue Shift I was pleasantly surprised by how exciting the ending was, I was not all let down by how it ended.

Now, while this Expansion has a less interesting arsenal than that of Opposing Force this didn't hinder it in any sort of way in my opinion. Gameplay remains the same, there aren't any new mechanics introduced, and there aren't any new enemy types. While this may sound like a letdown, I promise you it isn't. If you're looking for content similar to that of HL1 this expansion mimics that. This is primarily why I enjoyed this expansion more than Opposing Force which some may find strange. Its short length keeps Blue Shift from becoming too repetitive and boring due to the lack of enemy types and small arsenal. 

Everything considered, I believe this expansion to be a worthy part of Half-Life, and completely worth your time.

Half-life: Blue Shift takes 1-2 hours to beat and is the shortest of the three games that are available on steam.

Due to the decrease in length the game isn't as jam packed as Half-Life or it's for expansion Opposing Force. 

Blue Shift features less weapons than the original game and no new weapons for this game or from Opposing Force; All the weapons featured in this game are basic guns so you wont be using the Gluon gun or the TAU-Canon. 

There's also no memorable moments such as launching a rocket, being left behind by your HECU comrades, fighting a giant fetus, fighting a giant ballsack and you get it by now.

Another problem coming from this game is the lack of new enemies, either original or returning from Opposing Force; Released two years after the first expansion you would expect a longer more expanded game that fleshes out the Half-Life universe in terms of characters, locations and enemies but this game delivers on none of that since this games main supporting character Dr.Rosenberg was featured one year earlier in the PS2 expansion Half-Life: Decay.

Ultimately this game is disappointing after playing Half-Life and Opposing Force, but at the end of the day it's more Half-Life.

Half Life Blue Shift is the second main expansion to Half Life. This part of the HL1 saga puts you in the shoes of Barney Calhoun, everyone's favorite Black Mesa security guard who plays a more prominent role as one of the loveable characters of Half Life 2 in that game. But this expansion is a bit of a step down compared to Opposing force. It's still a very solid expansion, but worse nontheless. The role of a security guard is a less interesting perspective than the previous two, and there aren't really any new weapons or enemies introduced. Towards the end of the campaign you also visit Xen, but it's a lot more bearable than in the first game because it removes a lot of the annoying platforming. Despite some of the obvious similarities, it maintains the amazing worldbuilding, atmosphere, puzzles, and music that you can expect in a Half Life game. So if you're a fan of classic goldsource Half Life games then this should provide a short and sweet little taste of that for you, that I can easily reccommend to FPS fans.

A good game that's not without its frustrating moments. There's plenty of run and gun action interspersed with puzzles. Some of the puzzles though, feel more "I, Spy" than brain teasers. The level, "Power Struggle" almost can't be beat in two different areas unless you are super observant or you just happen to guess correctly--I say guess because the mechanics of the game aren't established so clearly in the beginning enough for a player to figure some moments out. 

SPOILER: one puzzle involving the use of a metal barrel to complete a circuit for a dynamite comes to mind--the gray metal barrel is surrounded by wooden crates so it's difficult to spot to begin with. 

Secondly, the dynamite on the metal door does not explode even if you shoot it with APC's, which is a problem because this logic puzzle relies on you understanding the game more than real logic. There's only one way to solve the puzzle, which is not intuitive because it's difficult to understand that the barrel could be used for anything. Another issue from an earlier level--a ladder is hidden behind a shadowy wall, and it was so difficult to find. 

Yet some other puzzles require creative arrangements of crates and barrels. It would've been fun had not the barrel arrangement require absolute precision on the player's part. Hours are spent fine-tuning barrel placements to get things to work.

Other than that, it was a fun diversion--short gameplay that felt long due to the repetitive nature of looking for these "I, Spy" elements. Half-Life Blue Shift was released in 2001, 2 years after Opposing Force and was too be the last of the expansion packs within the original Half-Life saga.

Blue shift represents the security division of the Black Mesa Research Facility, albeit, you are now in the eyes of the infamous "Barney Calhoun" a name synonymous within the HL community as a major character to the on-going series. This will undoubtedly tell the back story of Barney and his involvement during the catastrophe of Black Mesa. Thus will give you an understanding of his role to come, his relationship with Freeman and his adaptation going fourth into Half Life 2.

Blue-Shift very much so entwines itself into two other stories without any excessive elaboration. That of paths of Gordon Freeman (being the original Half-Life) and Adrian Sheppard (being Opposing Force). Many areas, perhaps actions and words will resonate as the story progresses and give you a "fly on the wall perspective" and interpretation of the events that unfolded for different persons within the Facility during the cataclysm.

Blue-Shift is a reasonably quick game and you are given a slimmer but similar inventory of HL weapons used by Freeman as opposed to Sheppard, who deviates in this area due to his mission statement and employment. Blue-Shift does not diverge from its conservative HL roots compared to the original, levels are similar but different, puzzles need to be completed to advance, scripted scenes without cut-scenes and the continual use of chapters.

Blue-Shift also came with an extra addition called the high definition pack, which comprised of better textures and models. I do applaud the devs in the early days, how Blue-Shift represents and perceives Black Mesa as more "lively and livable" with people going about their day, as opposed to the standpoint of other HL games. Furthermore as authentic as the half-life experience is being alone most of the time, Blue-Shift also incorporates more team work and interaction with scientists to achieve objectives.

However the game did come with mixed reviews, critical of the games length, no new enemies or weapons, compared to the other expansion Opposing Force. This did extend to the depth of the high definition pack and by extension of the games characters. I believe its rated poorly compared to the others.

Those reviews aside and as a long time gamer and Half-Life veteran myself I do believe they are are quite minor and it is nothing to compare to the likes of some modern games being released today.

The blue Half-Life as its called, is a nostalgic addition which takes many of us older gamers on a trip down memory lane. A  must play IMO as it does give perspective of a different protagonist and does wrap up their path until the events of HL2!

I believe a remake for Blue-Shift is still in the works (hopefully comparable to Black mesa remake!) so watch this space.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is an expansion pack for the FPS video game Half-Life. It takes the same place and time as in Half-Life and during its events, but now, instead of playing as Gordon Freeman, you are playing as a control security guard Barney Calhoun. After the incident in Black Mesa and all the ongoing mishaps, you with the help of Dr. Rosenberg, a high-ranking scientist try to evacuate the facility.

The expansion pack consists of a Training Room and 3 modes: Easy, Medium, and Hard.
The Training Room is exactly like the one in Half-Life, the only exception is the holographic Barney replacing Gina.
Now the modes:
1. Easy mode: The easiest thing you will ever play. Difficulty: 0/10;
2. Medium mode: Still easy, barely even a challenge, not even close to breaking a sweat. Difficulty: 1.5/10;
3. Hard mode: Finally something challenging, but not even close to the hard mode in Half-Life. Difficulty: 3.5/10.

Weapons: The same weapons in Half-Life, but the variety of weapons is reduced by half.

Multiplayer: This expansion pack has no multiplayer.

Overall it's a decent expansion pack. Worth to have it, especially if you like to indulge in the Half-Life universe.

[h1]Review of Half-Life: Blue Shift[/h1] 
The second official expansion to the original Half-Life, developed by Gearbox Software, putting you in the shoes of Barney Calhoun. A Black Mesa security guard, who's ready for another long & uneventful day on the job. I'm certain nothing at all would happen here at the Black Mesa Research Facility that could cause some kind of catastrophic emergency... Right? 

Originally a Sega Dreamcast exclusive chapter, was turned into a standalone PC experience after that console's short lifespan came to an end prior to Blue Shift's release. 

[i]I highly recommend you read my previous review first, on Half-Life, for greater context to my discussion.[/i]

[h1]Security Shift[/h1]
While Blue Shift was released after Opposing Force, like it & the original game, the events of the story canonically play out alongside each other. So there's no harm in playing this one before Opposing Force or even Half-Life. The references to said game, can be experienced both as someone jumping from this one to that one, or vice versa. Personally, I choose to play Blue Shift immediately after the original Half-Life. Due to its smaller content amount and shorter length in comparison.

It's quite enjoyable to be running parallel to the events of Half-Life. While still utilizing the same methods of story telling & world building. In-fact, you'll start your journey on a tram ride not unlike Gordon does. It's also quite interesting for it to be themed after the Black Mesa security branch. Instead of an HEV suit & its power, you rely on body armor. Instead of the classic orange HUD, you have a stylish and superior blue HUD (Don't @ me). Simultaneously giving us a different perspective of the Resonance Cascade event. It's exciting, not knowing when it's going to occur, but knowing it's coming. Then watching just how much chaos was unleashed across the facility first hand. There are multiple direct references to Half-Life, such as seeing Gordon more than once, Half-Life: Decay, at the time an upcoming PlayStation 2 exclusive co-op chapter, and Half-Life: Opposing Force, the first expansion. More importantly, as far as narrative is concerned, you'll learn just a tad more about what Black Mesa was up to that lead to the events of the original game. 

Barney Calhoun, an important character to the franchise's story, isn't just sitting around waiting for the whole thing to blow over. Like everyone, your main goal is the get the Hell out. Running through entirely new areas of Black Mesa, visiting the border world of Xen once more, and hopefully escaping with your skin still attached. However, the pacing of Blue Shift is quite a bit.. off, feeling. Of course, you cannot parallel one to one as each player's experience is going to be slightly different per game. Here though, events that you'd expect to come later in the original game, occur almost immediately in the story here, or after roughly an hour of play (Including an important Gordon scene). This isn't a complaint mind you, and I'm sure there's some sort of explanation to be given, just something I noticed. 

In regards to the pacing, if you were hoping for another Opposing Force style expansion, you're unfortunately going to be disappointed. The narrative additions and handful of new areas, are really the only 'new' content you can expect in Blue Shift. You'll not fight any new Xen creatures, or HECU, nor will you acquire any weapons/gadgets unique to this expansion. On the contrary, there's actually way less than the original game here. Only a handful of core weapons will be at your disposal. Not bad, but a let down if you were hoping for more like Opposing Force gave. I'd say overall, Blue Shift is mainly just about introducing Barney Calhoun, and how his journey leads to the next installment. With that being said, if feels as though areas are a bit more detailed than the Half-Life.
|
The length of an entire playthrough is also drastically shorter than the original game + Opposing Force. Coming in at a staggeringly low 1-2 hours. Leaning more towards the 2~ hour range for a first playthrough, perhaps. You can practically blink, and the game is over. As an add-on to your Half-Life experience, that's just an extra bit of playtime, but if you're treating this as it can be treated, a standalone experience, you may be underwhelmed. On top of that, the difficulty is far lower than previous titles. Ammunition also never really becoming an issue like it can in Half-Life. 

Across my short playthrough, I experienced a handful of bugs that did not occur in the original game (For me, at least). None of these were game breaking, but could be slightly annoying depending on your level of tolerance. The most common one I was experiencing was when dying from gibs, I would reload firing my gun continuously until I clicked to cancel out the firing. Even if I wasn't shooting upon death. Another I experienced was this strange... almost rubber banding effect where my mouse would snap around and I'd seemingly teleport a few feet. I was able to fix this issue with an online thread post. During the Xen portion, I managed to get stuck in mid air, but was able to free myself. 

[u]HD Pack[/u]
Released with Blue Shift was a high definition upgrade pack that covered the original game and its two expansions. It focused up upgrading weapon models, a handful of props/interactive objects, as well as some NPC's & creatures. The actual reception of this pack seems to be hit or miss among fans. I didn't mention it in my review of Half-Life, but you have the option to manually turn the HD pack on or off (It's on by default). I tend to keep it off, with the exception of Blue Shift, as it was released with it. 

Some of the new models look great in my opinion, while others completely rework the visuals of weapons, and can feel a bit out of place with the rest of the game's visuals. Weapons like the shotgun look great with the upgrade, but changing the classic Glock-17 to a Baretta isn't to my liking. I'm indifferent on the MP5 submachine change.

Unfortunately, no changes were made to the game's flashlight, as it doesn't mess with the engine's lighting mechanics. The flashlight being a bit of a difficult tool to use in the original game as well. 

[h1]Conclusion (Pros & Cons)[/h1] 
The best way I can describe Blue Shift is a bonus spurt of original Half-Life story, that sets up a character for the events that'll follow in the sequels. It is a downgrade in regards to playable content though, so take that as you will. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
+More story context
+Barney Calhoun's introduction
+Atmospheric storytelling
+Blue HUD

[b]Neutral:[/b]
~Insanely short (1-2 hours)
~Handful of none-game breaking bugs
~Vacant OST(?)
~HD Pack

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Large drop in difficulty

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
Thank you for taking the time to read my review. Please remember, that this is just my opinion. We don't have to agree, one thing I love you may hate, and one thing I hate you may love. Hopefully this gave you an idea of what to expect. 

[b]Review lengths have been greatly compressed due to the character limit.[/b]

This is the second, and the shortest expansion of the original Half Life game. Here you play as Barney Calhoun, one of the security guards at the Black Mesa Facility, and you help the scientist survive the invasion of the Marines and the Black Ops, while Gordon is trying to fight against the alien threat as seen in the original game. You will play through all the behind the scenes of the security guard’s journey and all he does while Gordon is away. 

Technically, this expansion is very similar to the original Half Life: You will find no new weapons, enemies or music. The gameplay itself is very similar too, of course without certain Gordon-specific mechanics and weapons. Graphically it does come with a high-resolution textures pack, and a very similar look and feel to the original game. 

So, this is quite a different take on an expansion when compared to Opposing Force, which has not only much more content and play time, but also a completely different feeling and atmosphere that made that expansion had an identity of its own. Although not as rich and complete as that first expansion, this one is still very interesting and worth playing, especially taking in consideration its reduced duration.

Even though this release is not completely canon, and you can certainly skip it and still understand the main storyline of the saga, I think that is quite an interesting and very fun short release that makes the player understand the importance of Barney for the next games. Going through the facility from his point of view does highlight a totally different perspective and makes you realize that Gordon was not the only one with an important role of saving Black Mesa. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who played and enjoyed the original Half Life.

Our favorite Black Mesa security guard (read unique Barney clone) goes on a adventure in order to escape Black Mesa.

lemme preface, when i say i recommend the game, i exclusively mean to those who want more half-life 1 style content. this is a very skippable entry however.

let's start with the pros: it's an expansion of half-life 1, a game i found so enjoyable, so the mechanics being mostly the same definitely made me enjoy it more. plus, the continuity between this game and the base game are fun to see. unfortunately, i did have more negatives with this game than i did the original.

the game took me 3 hours to finish and probably could've taken less if i hadn't made myself dinner midway through the game, leaving it idle on my pc. it's so short that you dont really get the chance to appreciate anything until the credits roll. this doesnt make the game bad, per se, but compared to the 15 hours i took in base half life, it was extremely underwhelming

adding onto that aspect, the last couple chapters felt very much like a chore. [spoiler]xen felt better than in half-life 1, but the last 2 chapters where you're trying to get the charged battery just felt very tedious and not as fun as the rest of the game.[/spoiler] it kind of felt like padding, as if they needed to reach some sort of playtime quota. a short game, especially as an expansion pack, can still be really fun, but feeling the need to expand this by 2 whole chapters that really didn't need to exist just made the game feel so much more arduous to complete.

the weapons were also very lackluster. [spoiler]since you arent playing as gordon, but rather as "b. calhoun" who is a security guard, thus only really having access to a pistol for a good portion of the game. you do get the shotgun, smg, and some explosives later on, but the experimental and alien weapons were inaccessible (except for the snarks, which i never use). i know that's for lore and continuity purposes, but it was still upsetting to only have some pretty basic weaponry.[/spoiler]

overall, yes i do recommend it, as it was very fun, but i would not classify it as a must-play if you are trying to get into half-life. there isnt much lore present here that wasnt already known from the first game and as such, it's very skippable. if all you care about is seeing the events of the black mesa incident from the point of view of that security guard you see on your tram ride, then this serves exactly that purpose. 6/10

This game is pretty good, a nice addition to the Half-Life series, but it's probably my least favorite game in the franchise and here's 3 reasons why:

1. The HD models; They just don't look that good. But I do think they fit better into the context of Blue Shift than they do in Half-Life, which makes them slightly tolerable here. 

2, The story isn't that great. I haven't played for much longer and the story is really basic. It's just Half-Life 1 from Barnie's perspective, I know Half-Life: Opposing Force is just HL1 from a HECU soldier's perspective, but the thing that made that game so good was the new content, the new enemies, weapons, and environments just make it way better than this.

3. This game just feels like extra levels for the base game of Half-Life. I know Opposing Force is also "technically" just extra levels, the reasons I listed above show why Opposing Force is just a better game.
